plants.name: Rudbeckia hirta
plants.description: A hardy flowering plant common in North American prairies and gardens, known for its bright yellow petals and dark brown central cone. It attracts pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
plants.funFact: Black-eyed Susans are often used in wildflower mixes to restore natural prairies and attract beneficial insects.

plants.name: Nerium oleander
plants.description: An evergreen shrub popular in Mediterranean climates, producing clusters of fragrant flowers throughout much of the year, but especially abundant in late summer to fall.
plants.location: Mediterranean Basin, Southern USA, and similar climates
plants.funFact: Oleander is highly toxic if ingested, yet it has been used medicinally in traditional medicine under strict conditions.

plants.name: Grevillea robusta
plants.description: A fast-growing Australian native tree with fern-like leaves and bright orange, brush-shaped flowers that bloom in late winter through to spring and sometimes into early fall in favorable climates.
plants.location: Eastern Australia and subtropical regions worldwide
plants.funFact: Despite its common name, Silky Oak is not a true oak but gets its name from its timber which has a silky texture.

plants.name: Fuchsia magellanica
plants.description: A deciduous shrub or small tree native to South America, producing elegant, pendulous flowers in vivid pinks and purples that bloom late summer through fall.
plants.location: Southern Chile and Argentina; widely cultivated in temperate zones
plants.funFact: Fuchsias are named after the German botanist Leonhart Fuchs and are popular for attracting hummingbirds during bloom.
